title: Why do people say Latin is a dead language while many doctors and historians keep using the words that are directly taken from Latin? - Quora

response.answer_text: The linguistic definition of a living language is that it should be spoken and understood by people in general basically for communication purposes. I suppose that is not the case with this language which is spoken and understood by common people. It once was a vibrant language. With the language becoming limited to a small section of people its status becomes reduced to a dead language. It doesn't mean that it can never be used as a language. There is no bar on its usage. If it continues to be used by substantial percentage of people in a given territory it will be deemed as a living language. This happened in the case of Hebrew as it is used by good number of people in Israel. It can happen to any language. So if the user group of a particular community in any given territory is used effectively for communication purposes it can be revived by any existing language. Correct, Latin is still in use in certain circles - doctors/historians use Latin words or expression, but do not converse entirely in Latin - but it is no longer the native tongue/language of an ethnic group or a community.
